documents.title: Order
documents.text:
9:20-cv-02144-DCN     Date Filed 08/01/23    Entry Number 104     Page 1 of 10
IN THE UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
FOR THE DISTRICT OF SOUTH CAROLINA 
BEAUFORT DIVISION 
 
CHERYL A. MUNDAY and      ) 
MARGARET DEVINE, on behalf of   ) 
themselves and others similarly situated,  ) 
            ) 
      Plaintiffs,    )  No. 9:20-cv-02144-DCN 
            ) 
vs.        )         ORDER 
            ) 
BEAUFORT COUNTY; PHILIP FOOT;  ) 
QUANDARA GRANT; JOHN DOES 1โ5;  ) 
and JANE DOES 1โ5,      ) 
            ) 
      Defendants.    ) 
____________________________________) 
 
This matter is before the court on defendant Beaufort Countyโs (โBeaufort 
Countyโ or the โCountyโ) motion for reconsideration, ECF No. 87, regarding the courtโs 
order, ECF No. 82, adopting in part and rejecting in part Magistrate Judge Molly 
Cherryโs report and recommendation (โR&Rโ), ECF No. 76, to grant in part and deny in 
part Beaufort Countyโs motion for summary judgment, ECF No. 48.  For the reasons set 
forth below, the court denies the motion.   
I.   BACKGROUND 
Because the parties are well acquainted with this litigation, the court will only 
briefly summarize material facts for the purpose of aiding an understanding of the courtโs 
legal analysis. 
1 
 

9:20-cv-02144-DCN     Date Filed 08/01/23    Entry Number 104     Page 2 of 10
This matter arises from certain procedures in place at the Beaufort County 
Detention Center1 (โBCDCโ) that are used for female pre-classification detainees.2  Once 
a pre-trial detainee goes to a bond hearing and cannot post a bond, upon returning to 
BCDC, he or she is then classified to a different area at BCDC, such as in general 
population or, depending on the inmateโs behavior, maximum or super maximum 
security.  ECF No. 34-3 at 21:3โ18.  On February 27, 2015, BCDC adopted a policy (the 
โpolicyโ) that all inmates moved from pre-classification to other areas of BCDC, 
including general population, would be strip searched.3  See ECF No. 31-4 at 2.  BCDCโs 
practice (the โpracticeโ) has been to house female pre-classification inmates in general 
population while placing male pre-classification inmates in a separate pre-classification 
cell outside of general population.  ECF No. 31-3 at 14, Black Dep. 24:2โ20.  Because 
female pre-classification inmates are housed in general population from the outset, the 
practice resulted in BCDC conducting a strip search on every female pre-classification 
detainee awaiting a bond hearing.  ECF No. 40-1 ยถ 6.  BCDC, however, did not do so for 
similarly situated male pre-classification detainees prior to May 5, 2020, because they 
were housed in a separate pre-classification cell outside of general population.   
The two named plaintiffs in this case, Cheryl Munday (โMundayโ) and Margaret 
Devine (โDevineโ) (together, โplaintiffsโ), allege they were impacted by this practice.  
 
1 Defendant Beaufort County operates BCDC. ECF Nos. 12 ยถ 7, 13 ยถ 5.   
2 A pre-classification detainee is an inmate who has been arrested and placed or 
housed in an area at the detention center prior to going to a bond hearing.  ECF No. 34-1 
at 20:7โ14.   
3 This policy of strip searching all inmates moved from pre-classification to other 
areas of the facility, including general population, was established in a memorandum (the 
โAllen Memorandumโ) from Deputy Director C.E. Allen published on February 27, 
2015.  See ECF No. 40-1 ยถ 6, Grant Aff.  
2 
 

9:20-cv-02144-DCN     Date Filed 08/01/23    Entry Number 104     Page 3 of 10
Specifically, each of them describes being arrested for driving under the influence (each 
had that charge later dismissed), brought into BCDC for holding, and subjected to a 
public strip search and visual body cavity searchโall while similarly situated men were 
not subjected to such a search.   
Plaintiffs filed the instant case on March 6, 2020, in the Beaufort County Court of 
Common Pleas on behalf of themselves and a class of all similarly situated women who 
were subjected to the practice and the policy.4  ECF No. 1-1, Compl.  On June 5, 2020, 
Beaufort County removed the case to federal court.  ECF No. 1.  This case was referred 
to Magistrate Judge Molly Cherry for all pretrial proceedings pursuant to the provisions 
of 28 U.S.C. ยง 636(b)(1)(A) and (B) and Local Civil Rule 73.02(B)(2)(g) (D.S.C.).  On 
August 5, 2020, plaintiffs filed an amended complaint, now the operative complaint.  
ECF No. 12, Amend. Compl.  The plaintiffs brought various state and federal claims 
against Beaufort County, Assistant County Administrator for the Public Safety Division 
Philip Foot (โFootโ), Director of the BCDC Colonel Quandara Grant (โDirector Grantโ), 
John Does 1โ5 (described as โBCDC Supervisory Defendantsโ), and Jane Does 1-5 
(described as โBCDC Officer Defendantsโ) (collectively, โdefendantsโ).  Amend. Compl. 
ยถยถ 7โ11. 
On May 2, 2022, defendants filed a motion for summary judgment.  ECF No. 48.  
On October 28, 2022, Magistrate Judge Cherry issued the R&R which recommended the 
 
4 Specifically, the class is defined as โall women who have been admitted to the 
Beaufort County Detention Center while waiting for bail to be set or for an initial court 
appearance, women who have been arrested on default warrants and held in the Beaufort 
County Detention Center, and women who have been held in protective custody in the 
Beaufort County Detention Center. . . . These women have all been unlawfully subjected 
to routine strip searches, including degrading visual body cavity searches of their anuses 
and vaginas.โ  Compl. ยถ 4.   
3 
 

9:20-cv-02144-DCN     Date Filed 08/01/23    Entry Number 104     Page 4 of 10
motion for summary judgment be granted in part and denied in part and recommended 
that plaintiffsโ request to amend their amended complaint to name new defendants be 
denied.  ECF No. 76, R&R.  On March 27, 2023, the court adopted in part and rejected in 
part the R&R which, in turn, granted in part and denied in part Beaufort Countyโs motion 
for summary judgment.  ECF No. 82.  On April 24, 2023, Beaufort County filed a motion 
for reconsideration.  ECF No. 87.  Plaintiffs responded in opposition on May 5, 2023, 
ECF No. 89, to which Beaufort County replied on May 12, 2023, ECF No. 90.  As such, 
the motion has been fully briefed and it is now ripe for review.   
II.   STANDARD 
A.  Motion to Alter or Amend 
Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 59(e) allows a party to file a motion to alter or 
amend a judgment.  The rule provides an โextraordinary remedy which should be used 
sparingly.โ  Pac. Ins. Co. v. Am. Natโl Fire Ins. Co., 148 F.3d 396, 403 (4th Cir. 1998) 
(internal quotation marks and citation omitted).  The Fourth Circuit recognizes โonly 
three limited grounds for a district courtโs grant of a motion under Rule 59(e): (1) to 
accommodate an intervening change in controlling law; (2) to account for new evidence 
not available earlier; or (3) to correct a clear error of law or prevent manifest injustice.โ  
Wilder v. McCabe, 2012 WL 1565631, at *1 (D.S.C. May 2, 2012) (citing Hutchinson v. 
Staton, 994 F.2d 1076 (4th Cir. 1993)).  To qualify for reconsideration under the third 
exception, an order cannot merely be โmaybe or probablyโ wrong; it must be โdead 
wrong,โ so as to strike the court โwith the force of a five-week-old, unrefrigerated dead 
fish.โ  TFWS, Inc. v. Franchot, 572 F.3d 186, 194 (4th Cir. 2009) (quoting Bellsouth 
Telesensor v. Info. Sys. & Networks Corp., 1995 WL 520978, at *5 n.6 (4th Cir. 1995) 
4 
 

9:20-cv-02144-DCN     Date Filed 08/01/23    Entry Number 104     Page 5 of 10
(unpublished)).  โA partyโs mere disagreement with the courtโs ruling does not warrant a 
Rule 59(e) motion, and such motion should not be used to โrehashโ arguments previously 
presented or to submit evidence which should have been previously submitted.โ  
Consulting Engโrs, Inc. v. Geometric Software Sols. & Structure Works LLC, 2007 WL 
2021901, at *2 (D.S.C. July 6, 2007).  Ultimately, the decision whether to reconsider an 
order resulting in judgment pursuant to Rule 59(e) is within the discretion of the district 
court.  See Hughes v. Bedsole, 48 F.3d 1376, 1382 (4th Cir. 1995). 
III.   DISCUSSION 
The court granted Beaufort Countyโs motion for summary judgment on Counts 1, 
3, 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, and 2 (as asserted against individual defendants), but denied Beaufort 
Countyโs motion for summary judgment on Counts 2 (violations of the Equal Protection 
Clause pursuant to 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 brought against Beaufort County) and 10 (attorneysโ 
fees under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1988(b)).  ECF No. 82 at 23.  Beaufort County now moves the 
court to alter or amend its order, ECF No. 82, to enter summary judgment in favor of 
Beaufort County as to plaintiffsโ equal protection claims brought under ยง 1983 (i.e., 
Counts 2 and 10).  ECF No. 87 at 2.   
Beaufort County argues that the court committed an error of law when it 
concluded that the searching of female pre-classification detainees was facially 
discriminatory, when the challenged classification was in fact โindisputably facially 
neutral.โ5  Id. at 3โ4.  In support of this contention, it cites to the Allen Memorandum 
 
5 To provide context to this argument, the court notes that according to the Fourth 
Circuit, unequal treatment constituting an equal protection violation โoccurs in one of 
two ways: (1) when the government explicitly classifies people based on [a suspect 
classification], or (2) when a law is facially neutral, but its administration or enforcement 
disproportionately affects one class of persons over another and a discriminatory intent or 
5 
 

9:20-cv-02144-DCN     Date Filed 08/01/23    Entry Number 104     Page 6 of 10
which specified that โall inmates moved from pre-classification to other areas of the 
Detention Center (which would include general population) be strip searched.โ  Id. at 4 
(emphasis in original).  Beaufort County argues that โ[t]he language of the Memorandum 
is, indisputably, gender neutral,โ because it โnever mentions or discusses sex in any 
way.โ  Id. at 5.  Thus, it concludes that โ[t]he challenged conductโsearching all pre-
classification female detaineesโis an obvious application of the policies embodied in the 
facially-neutral Memorandum.โ  Id.  Further, Beaufort County argues that [t]here is no 
evidence that the County made a conscious decision to specifically search women 
because of their gender.โ  Id. at 5โ6.  Thus, it contends that โthe Court made a legal error 
in shifting its focus from the facially-neutral search rules to their allegedly gender-
discriminatory impact.โ  Id. at 6 (emphasis in original).  โ[T]he only evidence is that pre-
classification female detainees were only search [sic] because of their location,โ and 
โthere is no evidence of any policy, practice, custom, or intention that anyone be searched 
specifically because of her sex.โ  Id. (emphasis in original).  Beaufort County concludes 
that โthe Courtโs determination that there is a facially discriminatory classification 
disregards the requirement of proof of intent.โ  Id. at 7.  The County concedes that its 
practice had an unequal impact on women, but it argues that is not enough because the 
plaintiffs must show disparate impact and discriminatory purpose or intent, which the 
County argues that plaintiffs have not adequately shown.  Id. at 8โ9 (citing Flores v. City 
 
animus is shown.โ  Monroe v. City of Charlottesville, 579 F.3d 380, 388 (4th Cir. 2009).  
Thus, Beaufort County argues that the court improperly applied the first prong when it 
found an explicit classification on the basis of a protected class, when the appropriate 
standard of review for the actions in question should have come from the second prong 
where the policy was facially neutral but caused a disparate impact.  See ECF No. 87 at 
3โ4.   
6 
 

9:20-cv-02144-DCN     Date Filed 08/01/23    Entry Number 104     Page 7 of 10
of N.Y., 2021 WL 663977, at *6 (E.D.N.Y. Feb. 19, 2021)).  As such, Beaufort County 
concludes that the court improperly found the policy and the practice facially 
discriminatory when the policy was facially neutral.  Id. at 8โ9. 
In response, plaintiffs emphasize that the courtโs order denying summary 
judgment on the ยง 1983 claim was correct because Beaufort Countyโs actual practice is 
facially discriminatory and requires no proof of intent.  ECF No. 89 at 2.  Plaintiffs 
contend that the Countyโs argument โis like saying that racially segregated bathrooms 
treated everyone equally, because everyone was prohibited from using the bathroom of a 
different race,โ which is, in essence, asking the court โto ignore the distinction between 
policy versus practice.โ  Id. at 2โ3.  Plaintiffs go on to claim that โ[i]f the Court adopts 
[Beaufort Countyโs] logic, state actors like BCDC will avoid constitutional liability by 
whitewashing their written policies even when their actions are facially discriminatory.โ  
Id. at 5 (emphasis in original).   
In reply, Beaufort County argues, once more, that the policy at issue is facially 
sex-neutral and, consequently, under a disparate impact analysis plaintiffs โmust create a 
genuine issue of material fact regarding discriminatory intent to survive summary 
judgment, which they have not done (and cannot do).โ  ECF No. 90 at 1.  Beaufort 
County argues that its liability under Section 1983 โis limited to constitutional violations 
caused by official policy or custom.โ  Id. at 4 (quoting Littleton v. Swonger, 502 F. 
Appโx 271, 277 (4th Cir. 2012) (internal citations and quotation marks omitted)).  This 
means that a โpolicy or custom may be written ordinances and regulations, affirmative 
decisions of individual policymaking officials, omissions by policymaking officials that 
manifest deliberate indifference to the rights of citizens, and practices so persistent and 
7 
 

9:20-cv-02144-DCN     Date Filed 08/01/23    Entry Number 104     Page 8 of 10
widespread as to constitute a custom or usage with the force of law.โ  Id. (citing Carter v. 
Morris, 164 F.3d 215, 218 (4th Cir. 1999)).  Thus, Beaufort County claims that the Allen 
Memorandum contains the official policy or custom at issue being challenged because it 
established the facially neutral policy of searching all detainees moved from pre-
classification to another part of the prison, and not the practice of only moving and 
searching female detainees.  Id.  Finally, Beaufort County argues that the relevant 
policymaker, Director Grant, is a woman and member of the protected class, which 
โundermines any claim of discriminatory intent.โ  Id. at 8โ9 (providing a string cite of 
cases where courts purportedly found no discriminatory intent because the decisionmaker 
was part of the impacted class).   
To reiterate, for the court to alter or amend its order under the third exception of 
Fed. R. Civ. P. 59(e), an order cannot merely be โmaybe or probablyโ wrong; it must be 
โdead wrong,โ so as to strike the court โwith the force of a five-week-old, unrefrigerated 
dead fish.โ  TFWS, 572 F.3d at 194.  โA partyโs mere disagreement with the courtโs 
ruling does not warrant a Rule 59(e) motion, and such motion should not be used to 
โrehashโ arguments previously presented or to submit evidence which should have been 
previously submitted.โ  Consulting Engโrs, Inc., 2007 WL 2021901, at *2.   
Beaufort County presented nearly identical argumentsโthat the policy was 
facially neutral and that plaintiffs failed to create a genuine dispute of material fact 
regarding discriminatory intentโin its objections to the R&R, ECF No. 79 at 9โ11, and 
its motion for summary judgment, ECF No. 48-1 at 11โ13, which the court thoroughly 
reviewed and found to be without merit.  See ECF No. 82 at 8โ11.  The court reminds 
Beaufort County that a Rule 59(e) motion โmay not be used to relitigate old matters, or to 
8 
 

9:20-cv-02144-DCN     Date Filed 08/01/23    Entry Number 104     Page 9 of 10
raise arguments or present evidence that could have been raised prior to the entry of 
judgment.โ  Pac. Ins. Co., 148 F.3d at 403 (internal citation and quotation marks 
omitted).  Beaufort County asserted neither of the first two grounds for reconsideration; 
the third ground is not available either: Beaufort County has not shown that the court 
made a clear error of law, nor has it argued that the courtโs decision must be reconsidered 
to prevent manifest injustice.  See Hutchinson, 994 F.2d at 1081.  The court reiterates its 
conclusion from its order:  
[T]he  action  challenged  is  BCDCโs  practice  of  placing  male  pre-
classification  detainees  in  housing  separate  from  general  population 
inmatesโwhich  meant  they  were  not  automatically  subjected  to  strip 
searchesโwhereas  female  pre-classification  detainees  were  placed  in 
general population and were always subjected to strip searches. . . .  Had 
plaintiffs  been  male,  they  would  have  been  placed  in  separate  pre-
classification detainee housing and would have in all likelihood avoided the 
strip  search.    Consequently,  BCDCโs  practice  clearly  falls  under  the 
category of facial sex discrimination. 
ECF No. 82 at 11.  Far from being clear error, the courtโs decision was factually 
supported and legally justified.  See id. (quoting Bauer v. Lynch, 812 F.3d 340, 347โ48 
(4th Cir. 2016) (โ[T]he Supreme Court outlined . . . a simple test for identifying facial sex 
discrimination: such discrimination appears where the evidence shows treatment of a 
person in a manner which but for that personโs sex would be differentโ) (internal 
quotation marks omitted and emphasis added).  Beaufort Countyโs โmere disagreementโ 
with the courtโs consideration of the practice at issue, versus the policy, โdoes not support 
a Rule 59(e) motion.โ  See id. at 1082.   
IV.   CONCLUSION 
  For the foregoing reasons the court DENIES the motion to reconsider.   
   
   
9 
 

9:20-cv-02144-DCN     Date Filed 08/01/23    Entry Number 104     Page 10 of 10
AND IT IS SO ORDERED. 
 
 
 
DAVID C. NORTON 
        UNITED STATES DISTRICT JUDGE 
 
August 1, 2023 
Charleston, South Carolina 
 
10

documents.title: Report and Recommendation and Order
documents.text:
9:20-cv-02144-DCN       Date Filed 10/28/22      Entry Number 76       Page 1 of 39
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
DISTRICT OF SOUTH CAROLINA 
BEAUFORT DIVISION 
 
Cheryl A. Munday and Margaret Devine, on  )  C/A No. 9:20-02144-DCN-MHC 
behalf of themselves and others similarly  )   
situated,  )   
  )   
        Plaintiffs,  )  REPORT AND RECOMMENDATION 
  )  AND ORDER 
  v.  ) 
  ) 
Beaufort County, Philip Foot, Quandara  ) 
Grant, John Does 1-5, and Jane Does 1-5,  ) 
  ) 
        Defendants.  ) 
  ) 
 
Before the Court is Defendantsโ Motion for Summary Judgment (โMotionโ). ECF No. 48. 
Plaintiffs filed a Response in Opposition to the Motion (ECF No. 56)1, and Defendants filed a 
Reply (ECF No. 63). The Motion is ripe for review.2  
BACKGROUND 
This case involves certain procedures used for female pre-classification detainees at the 
Beaufort County Detention Center (โBCDCโ or โDetention Centerโ). A pre-classification detainee 
is an inmate who has been arrested and placed or housed in an area at the detention center prior to 
going to a bond hearing. ECF No. 34-1 at 20:7โ14. Once a pre-trial detainee goes to a bond hearing 
and cannot produce a bond, upon returning to BCDC, he or she is then classified to a different area 
 
1 Within their Response, Plaintiffs seek leave to amend their Amended Complaint several times. 
Although no formal motion has been filed, the undersigned addresses Plaintiffsโ requests for leave 
to amend at the appropriate substantive sections herein. 
  
2 All pretrial proceedings in this case were referred to the undersigned pursuant to the provisions 
of 28 U.S.C. ยง 636(b)(1)(A) and (B) and Local Civil Rule 73.02(B)(2)(f) (D.S.C.). Pursuant to 
those provisions, this Report and Recommendation is entered for review by the District Judge. 

9:20-cv-02144-DCN       Date Filed 10/28/22      Entry Number 76       Page 2 of 39
at BCDC, such as in general population or, depending on the inmateโs behavior, maximum or super 
maximum security. ECF No. 34-3 at 21:3โ18. 
Defendant Beaufort County operates BCDC. ECF Nos. 12 ยถ 7, 13 ยถ 5. Defendant Philip 
Foot (โFootโ) is the Assistant County Administrator for Public Safety Division who oversees  
BCDC. ECF Nos. 12 at ยถ 8, 13 ยถ 6. Defendant Quandara Grant (โGrantโ) is a Colonel and the 
director of the BCDC. ECF Nos. 12 at ยถ 9, 13 ยถ 6. Defendants John Does 1โ5 are described in the 
Amended Complaint as โBCDC Supervisory Defendantsโ responsible for the training, supervision, 
control, assignment, and discipline of County personnel at BCDC, and for the formulation, 
administration, and enforcement of the policies, rules, regulations, and practices of BCDC. ECF 
No. 12 at  ยถ 10. Defendants Jane Does 1โ5 are described in the Amended Complaint as โBCDC 
Officer Defendantsโ who were, at all times relevant to this action, Beaufort County employees 
who worked as correctional officers at BCDC. Id. at ยถ 11. 
BDCD Strip Search Policy and Practice 
Prior to February 27, 2015, pursuant to BCDC policy, female pre-classification detainees 
were not strip searched,3 unless reasonable suspicion existed. ECF No. 40-1 at ยถ 5. Moreover, at 
that time, no inmate was strip searched upon going into BCDCโs general population, absent a 
specific reason. ECF No. 48-2 at 5, Grant Dep. at 52:7โ53:9. According to Defendants, this policy 
resulted in the passing of contraband from pre-classification inmates going into the general 
population. Id.  
 
3 The terms โstrip searchโ and โvisual body cavity searchโ (vbc) are used throughout this Report 
and Recommendation and, and at times, the term โstrip/vbc searchโ may be used. A strip search 
involves partial or complete disrobing but not necessarily a body cavity inspection, while a visual 
body cavity search involves visual inspection of rectal, vaginal and other body cavities. Strip/vbc 
searches involve removal of all clothing to permit inspection of all body openings including ears, 
nostrils, anus, navel, and mouth. ECF No. 31-2. They include a thorough inspection of the hair, 
crotch area, abdomen, soles of the feet, armpits, and areas between the fingers and toes. Id.  
2 
 

9:20-cv-02144-DCN       Date Filed 10/28/22      Entry Number 76       Page 3 of 39
On February 27, 2015, BCDC adopted a policy (โPolicyโ) that all inmates being moved 
from pre-classification to other areas of BCDC, including general population, would be strip 
searched. The Policy provides in relevant part: 
Sub:  Strip Search of all Inmates leaving Pre-Class 
1.  Effective this date all inmates being moved from Pre-Class to other areas of the 
facility will be strip-searched as a matter of policy. 
 
2.  The Pre-Class officer assisted by other members of the shift will strip search all 
inmates that are being moved by Classifications to other areas of the facility, as 
part of the process of changing uniforms.  
 
ECF No. 40-1 at ยถ 6.4 
BCDCโs practice (โPracticeโ) has been to house female pre-classification inmates in 
general population while placing male pre-classification inmates in a separate pre-classification 
cell outside of general population. ECF No. 31-3 at 14, Black Dep. 24:2โ20. Because female pre-
classification detainees are held in general population at the outset, BCDC conducts a strip/vbc 
search on every female pre-classification detainee5 awaiting a bond hearing. ECF No. 40-1 at ยถ 6. 
BCDC did not, however, do so for similarly situated male pre-classification detainees prior to May

LEGAL STANDARD 
Summary judgment is appropriate if a party โshows there is no genuine dispute as to any 
issue of material factโ and that the movant is entitled to judgment as a matter of law. Fed. R. Civ. 
P. 56(a). Under the framework established in Celotex Corp. v. Catrett, 477 U.S. 317 (1986), the 
party seeking summary judgment shoulders the initial burden of demonstrating to the Court that 
there is no genuine issue of material fact. Id. at 323. Once the movant has made this threshold 
demonstration,  the  non-moving  party,  to  survive  the  motion  for  summary  judgment,  must 
demonstrate that specific, material facts exist which give rise to a genuine issue. Id. at 324. 
Under this standard, the evidence of the non-moving party is to be believed and all 
justifiable inferences must be drawn in favor of the non-moving party. See Anderson v. Liberty 
Lobby, Inc., 477 U.S. 242, 255 (1986). However, although the Court views all the underlying facts 
and inferences in the record in the light most favorable to the non-moving party, the non-moving 
โparty nonetheless must offer some โconcrete evidence from which a reasonable juror could return 
a verdict in his [or her] favor.โโ Williams v. Genex Servs., LLC, 809 F.3d 103, 109 (4th Cir. 2015) 
(quoting Anderson, 477 U.S. at 256). That is to say, the existence of a mere scintilla of evidence 
in support of the plaintiffโs position is insufficient to withstand the summary judgment motion. 
Anderson, 477 U.S. at 252. Likewise, conclusory or speculative allegations or denials, without 
more, are insufficient to preclude the granting of the summary judgment motion. Thompson v. 
Potomac Elec. Power Co., 312 F.3d 645, 649 (4th Cir. 2002). โOnly disputes over facts that might 
6 
 

9:20-cv-02144-DCN       Date Filed 10/28/22      Entry Number 76       Page 7 of 39
affect the outcome of the suit under the governing law will properly preclude the entry of summary 
judgment. Factual disputes that are irrelevant or unnecessary will not be counted.โ Anderson, 477 
U.S. at 248. To survive summary judgment, the non-movant must provide evidence of every 
element essential to his action on which he will bear the burden of proving at a trial on the merits. 
Celotex Corp., 477 U.S. at 322. 
LEGAL ANALYSIS 
A. Plaintiffsโ Claims Under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983   
โSection 1983 of Title 42 creates a cause of action against any person who, acting under 
color of state law, abridges a right arising under the Constitution or laws of the United States.โ 
Cooper v. Sheehan, 735 F.3d 153, 158 (4th Cir. 2013). Section 1983 โis not itself a source of 
substantive  rights,  but  merely  provides  a  method  for  vindicating  federal  rights  elsewhere 
conferred.โ Albright v. Oliver, 510 U.S. 266, 271 (1994) (internal quotation marks omitted).   
Plaintiffs bring two claims under ยง 1983, alleging that Defendants violated their rights 
under the Fourth Amendment (Count 1) and the Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth 
Amendment (Count 2).  Defendants have moved for summary judgment on both claims. 
1.   Fourth Amendment (Count 1) 
Plaintiffs allege that Defendants subjected them to โunnecessary, demeaning, outrageous 
and intrusive strip and body cavity search[es]โ that violated their rights to be secure โagainst 
unreasonable searches and seizures as guaranteed by the Fourth and Fourteenth Amendments to 
the United States.โ ECF No. 12 at ยถ 48.  
The Fourth Amendment guarantees citizens the right โto be secure in their persons . . . 
against unreasonable searches and seizures.โ U.S. Const., Amend. IV; see Mapp v. Ohio, 367 U.S. 
643, 655 (1961) (finding that the Fourth Amendment is made applicable to the states through the 
7 
 

9:20-cv-02144-DCN       Date Filed 10/28/22      Entry Number 76       Page 8 of 39
Fourteenth Amendment). It is well established that assessing a searchโs reasonableness โrequires 
a balancing of the need for the particular search against the invasion of personal rights that the 
search entails.โ Bell v. Wolfish, 441 U.S. 520, 559 (1979). In conducting this analysis, โ[c]ourts 
must consider the scope of the particular intrusion, the manner in which it is conducted, the 
justification for initiating it, and the place in which it is conducted.โ Id. The Fourth Circuit employs 
the Bell test โto determine the reasonableness of a broad range of sexually invasive searches,โ 
including strip searches and visual body cavity searches. United States v. Edwards, 666 F.3d 877, 
883 (4th Cir. 2011) (internal quotation marks omitted) (strip search of arrestee); see Calloway v. 
Lokey, 948 F.3d 194, 201 (4th Cir. 2020) (strip search of prison visitor); Leverette v. Bell, 247 F.3d 
160 (4th Cir. 2001) (visual body cavity search of prison employee). 
In Bell, the United States Supreme Court held that a prison policy requiring all inmates and 
pretrial detainees to submit to visual body cavity searches following contact visits did not violate 
the Fourth Amendment. See 441 U.S. at 558 (โ[Although p]retrial detainees [] retain some Fourth 
Amendment rights upon commitment to a corrections facility, we nonetheless conclude that these 
searches do not violate that Amendment. The Fourth Amendment prohibits only unreasonable 
searches, and under the circumstances, we do not believe that these searches are unreasonable.โ) 
(internal citations omitted); Calloway, 948 F.3d at 201 (โWhile the [Bell] Court recognized that 
such searches were invasive, it reasoned that they were nonetheless reasonable even absent 
individualized  suspicion  in  light  of  the  prison officialsโ  โsignificant  and  legitimate  security 
interests.โโ) (quoting Bell, 441 U.S. at 560); Frazier v. Kimbrell, C/A No. 4:19-2384-MGL-TER, 
2021 WL 1799346, at *3 (D.S.C. Apr. 12, 2021) (โA body cavity search does not violate an 
inmateโs Fourth Amendment rights if the search is reasonable and not motivated by punitive 
8 
 

9:20-cv-02144-DCN       Date Filed 10/28/22      Entry Number 76       Page 9 of 39
intent.โ) (citing Bell, 441 U.S. at 545โ46, 558โ61), report and recommendation adopted, 2021 WL 
1791455.   
In 2012, the Supreme Court held that the Fourth Amendment does not prohibit a policy 
requiring the strip searching of all detainees who will be in a jailโs general population:  
The admission of inmates creates numerous risks for facility staff, for the existing 
detainee population, and for a new detainee himself or herself. . . . Detecting 
contraband  concealed  by  new  detainees,  furthermore,  is  a  most  serious 
responsibility. Weapons, drugs, and alcohol all disrupt the safe operation of a jail. 
. . . Something as simple as an overlooked pen can pose a significant danger. 
Inmates commit more than 10,000 assaults on correctional staff every year and 
many more among themselves. . . . There is a substantial interest in preventing any 
new inmate, either of his own will or as a result of coercion, from putting all who 
live or work at these institutions at even greater risk when he is admitted to the 
general population. . . .  
 
Florence v. Board of Chosen Freeholders, 566 U.S. 318, 333โ34 (2012); see id. at 340 (โThe Court 
holds that jail administrators may require all arrestees who are committed to the general population 
of a jail to undergo visual strip searches not involving physical contact by corrections officers.โ) 
(Alito, J., concurring).

Plaintiffs make no argument in their Response regarding their Fourth Amendment claim

she had not intended to abandon those claims), affโd sub nom. Jones v. Fam. Health Centers, Inc., 
98 F. Appโx 959 (4th Cir. 2004). Accordingly, the undersigned recommends granting Defendantsโ 
Motion for Summary Judgment as to any Fourth Amendment claims against Beaufort County.

2.  Equal Protection Clause (Count 2) 
Plaintiffs allege that the unequal treatment of men and women detainees deprived them of 
โclearly  established  protections  afforded  by  the  equal  protection  guarantees  of  the  14th 
Amendment.โ ECF No. 12 at ยถ 53. Specifically, Plaintiffs claim that the procedures used by BCDC 
between February 27, 2015, and May 5, 2020, to process the intake of similarly situated female 
and male pretrial detainees were different because, while all women in pre-classification status 
were housed in general population and subjected to routine strip/vbc searches, similarly-situated 
men in pre-classification status were not. ECF No. 12 ยถยถ 4, 25โ28. 
The Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment provides that no State shall 
โdeny to any person within its jurisdiction the equal protection of the laws.โ U.S. Const. amend. 
11 
 

9:20-cv-02144-DCN       Date Filed 10/28/22      Entry Number 76       Page 12 of 39
XIV, ยง 1. The Clause โis essentially a direction that all persons similarly situated should be treated 
alike.โ Fisher v. King, 232 F.3d 391, 399 (4th Cir. 2000) (quoting City of Cleburne v. Cleburne 
Living Ctr., 473 U.S. 432, 439 (1985)).  
โAn equal protection violation occurs in one of two ways: (1) when the government 
explicitly  classifies  people  based  on  [sex],  or  (2) when  a  law  is  facially  neutral,  but  its 
administration or enforcement disproportionately affects one class of persons over another and a 
discriminatory intent or animus is shown.โ Monroe v. City of Charlottesville, 579 F.3d 380, 388 
(4th Cir. 2009). Thus, to analyze a claim under the Equal Protection Clause, the first step is to 
identify the classification at issue. That determination, in turn, informs the governmentโs burden 
of proof.  
Certain laws or regulations distinguish among groups on their face. Others are facially-
neutral but nonetheless disproportionately affect certain groups. With respect to the latter category, 
a viable Equal Protection claim exists only when the plaintiff can demonstrate that a disparate 
impact and discriminatory intent nonetheless lie behind the facially-neutral law. See, e.g., Pers. 
Admโr of Mass. v. Feeney, 442 U.S. 256, 272โ74 (1979); Veney v. Wyche, 293 F.3d 726, 730โ31 
(4th Cir. 2002) (โTo succeed on an equal protection claim, [a detainee] โmust first demonstrate 
that [s]he has been treated differently from others with whom [s]he is similarly situated and that 
the unequal treatment was the result of intentional or purposeful discrimination.โโ) (quoting 
Morrison v. Garraghty, 239 F.3d 648, 654 (4th Cir. 2001)). By contrast, with respect to the former, 
where a line is overtly drawn on the basis of gender, a suspect classification is established by 
definition and there is no need to establish discriminatory intent. 
12 
 

9:20-cv-02144-DCN       Date Filed 10/28/22      Entry Number 76       Page 13 of 39
If a plaintiff makes either showing, โthe court proceeds to determine whether the disparity 
in treatment can be justified under the requisite level of scrutiny.โ Veney, 293 F.3d at 731 (quoting 
Morrison, 239 F.3d at 654). 
a.  Beaufort County 
i.  Different Treatment 
According to Defendants, the Court need not engage in any scrutiny at all (and they need 
not advance any justification for their actions) because a valid Equal Protection claim must 
establish that women were treated differently from men and that such unequal treatment stemmed 
from a discriminatory intent. Defendants argue that, while women and men pretrial detainees were 
undoubtedly treated differently, it was the result of a facially neutral policy that requires all 
detainees moving to general population, male and female, to be strip searched. ECF No. 48-1 at 
12โ13.  They  contend,  under  the  circumstances,  Plaintiffs  have  toโโand  cannotโโshow 
discriminatory intent, such that their claim fails.   
This argument ignores, however, that BCDCโs Policy, which applies to inmates โbeing 
moved from Pre-Class to other areas of the facility,โ is not at issue in this case. Rather, Plaintiffsโ 
claims are based upon their pre-classification status alone, at the outset of their arrest, not their 
movement from pre-classification to any other area of the facility.9 ECF No. 12 at ยถยถ 25, 27. 
Indeed, it is undisputed that BCDCโs Practice was to conduct a strip search on every female pre-

detainees were housed in general population at the outset, while male pretrial detainees were not. 
The separate housing, in and of itself, is not facially neutral but, instead, an explicit classification 
based on sex. See Monroe, 579 F.3d at 388. This explicit classification, which resulted in the strip 
searching of female pretrial detainees but not male pretrial detainees, is subject to scrutiny, as

classification detainee awaiting bond between February 27, 2015, and May 5, 2020, but not on

Viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to Plaintiffs, the undersigned agrees with 
Plaintiffs that BCDCโs Practice of strip-searching female pre-classification detainees but not male

ii.  Scrutiny 
State action that is explicitly based on sex generally is subject to certain scrutiny, and the 
burden is on the State to justify its action thereunder.10 United States v. Virginia, 518 U.S. 515, 
533 (1996). The Fourth Circuit has explained that when equal protection challenges arise in a 
 
10 Defendants argue in their initial brief that BCDCโs strip search Policy is subject to intermediate 
scrutiny. ECF No. 48-1 at 13โ15.  โIntermediate scrutiny, [ ]means โit must be established at least 
that  the  challenged  classification  serves  important  governmental  objectives  and  that  the 
discriminatory means employed are substantially related to the achievement of those objectives.โโ 
Adkins v. Rumsfeld, 464 F.3d 456, 468 (4th Cir. 2006) (quoting Nguyen v. INS, 533 U.S. 53, 60 
(2001)). However, for the first time in Reply, Defendants argue that a more relaxed constitutional 
standard applies. ECF No. 63 at 9โ12. The undersigned has analyzed the issues in this case under 
a more relaxed standard, as explained above. 
14 
 

9:20-cv-02144-DCN       Date Filed 10/28/22      Entry Number 76       Page 15 of 39
prison or jail context, โcourts must adjust the level of scrutiny to ensure that prison officials are 
afforded the necessary discretion to operate their facilities in a safe and secure manner.โ Veney, 
293 F.3d at 732 (evaluating equal protection claim brought by jail inmate). Under this more 
deferential standard, courts must determine whether the disparate treatment is โreasonably related 
to [any] legitimate penological interests.โ Id. (explaining that while courts are to โapply this 
deferential standard even when the alleged infringed constitutional right would otherwise warrant 
higher scrutiny[,] . . . this more deferential review does not make [the court] ignorant to the 
concerns that justify application of a heightened standard outside of the prison contextโ) (citation 
and internal quotation marks omitted). 
In determining whether an action is reasonable under this deferential standard, courts 
consider the following factors: (1) whether there is a valid, rational connection between the policy 
and penological interest; (2) whether an alternative means of exercising the right remains available 
to the inmate; (3) the impact accommodation of the asserted right will have on guards, other 
inmates, and the allocation of prison resources; and (4) the absence of ready alternatives that 
accommodate prisonersโ rights at de minimis cost to valid penological interests. Morrison, 239 
F.3d at 655 (citing Turner v. Safley, 482 U.S. 78, 89โ90 (1987)). The undersigned concludes that 
even under Morrisonโs less rigorous standard, Plaintiffs have set forth sufficient evidence to 
support an Equal Protection claim against BCDC, at least at this stage of the litigation. 
Here, with regard to the first factor, Defendants emphasize that all female pre-classification 
detainees, unlike their male counterparts, were held in the jailโs general population area where 
weapons and contraband posed a danger. ECF No. 48-1 at 14. As such, they contend they โhad a 
legitimate penological interest in preventing the smuggling of contraband into general population.โ 
ECF No. 63 at 12.  
15

penological interests that [the court] must consider.โ).  Notably, Defendants cite to Florence v. Bd. 
of  Chosen  Freeholders,  566  U.S.  318  (2012),  for  the  proposition  that  โgeneral  population 
dramatically magnifies the dangers posed by weapons and other contraband.โ Id. However, while 
the Florence case acknowledged jail officials may strip search individuals who have been arrested

ECF No. 56-1.

This argument segues into the fourth Morrison factor: the absence of ready alternatives

As to the first alternative, Defendants argue that BCDC could not modify its existing

This argument, however, is unavailing at this stage in the litigation. Indeed, at least some 
courts have recognized that such โneutral realities,โ id., are not sufficient to justify treating male 
and female inmates differently: โVague and general references to funding and space constraints 
cannot justify a policy that resulted directly in the strip and visual body cavity searches of 
thousands of female arrestees, while permitting their male counterparts to rest in the relative 
comfort and security of [ ] lockups.โ Ford v. Suffolk County, 154 F. Supp. 2d 131, 151 (D. Mass. 
2001); see also Bukhari v. Hutto, 487 F. Supp. 1162, 1171โ72 (E.D. Va. 1980) (โThe Court 
sympathizes with defendants who must deal with the fiscal reality that providing for a wide range 
of programs for a smaller number of prisoners entails a greater cost. However, such seemingly 
practical considerations may not be used to justify official inaction or legislative unwillingness to

operate a prison system in a constitutional manner.โ) (citations and internal quotation marks

9:20-cv-02144-DCN       Date Filed 10/28/22      Entry Number 76       Page 20 of 39
Under  the  doctrine  of  qualified  immunity,  โ[p]ublic  officials  are  immune  from  suit 
under 42 U.S.C. ยง 1983 unless they have violated a statutory or constitutional right that was clearly 
established at the time of the challenged conduct.โ City & Cty. of San Francisco, Calif. v. Sheehan, 
575 U.S. 600, 611 (2015); Iko v. Shreve, 535 F.3d 225, 237 (4th Cir. 2008) (explaining that 
pursuant  to  qualified  immunity,  โgovernment  officials  performing  discretionary  functions 
generally are shielded from liability for civil damages insofar as their conduct does not violate 
clearly established statutory or constitutional rights of which a reasonable person would have 
knownโ); see also Pearson v. Callahan, 555 U.S. 223, 231 (2009) (โQualified immunity balances 
two important interestsโthe need to hold public officials accountable when they exercise power 
irresponsibly and the need to shield officials from harassment, distraction, and liability when they 
perform their duties reasonably. The protection of qualified immunity applies regardless of 
whether the government officialโs error is a mistake of law, a mistake of fact, or a mistake based 
on mixed questions of law and fact.โ) (internal quotation marks omitted); Maciariello v. Sumner, 
973 F.2d 295, 298 (4th Cir. 1992) (โOfficials are not liable for bad guesses in gray areas; they are 
liable for transgressing bright lines.โ). 
In resolving questions of qualified immunity at summary judgment, courts engage in a two-
pronged inquiry: (1) โwhether the facts, taken in the light most favorable to the party asserting the 
injury, show the officerโs conduct violated a federal rightโ; and (2) โwhether the right in question 
was โclearly establishedโ at the time of the violation.โ Tolan v. Cotton, 572 U.S. 650, 655โ56 
(2014) (internal quotation marks and citations omitted). In the Fourth Circuit, plaintiffs bear the 
burden of proof to show that a constitutional violation occurred, while โdefendants bear the burden 
of showing that the violation was not clearly established, and they are therefore entitled to qualified 
immunity.โ Mays v. Sprinkle, 992 F.3d 295, 302 n.5 (4th Cir. 2021). Courts have discretion to 
20 
 

9:20-cv-02144-DCN       Date Filed 10/28/22      Entry Number 76       Page 21 of 39
decide the order in which to consider these two prongs. Pearson, 555 U.S. at 236; see Adams v. 
Ferguson, 884 F.3d 219, 226 (4th Cir. 2018) (explaining that courts can โskip ahead to the question 
whether the law clearly established that the officerโs conduct was unlawful in the circumstances 
of the caseโ) (quoting Pearson, 555 U.S. at 232) (internal quotation marks omitted). โBut under 
either prong, courts may not resolve genuine disputes of fact in favor of the party seeking summary 
judgment.โ Tolan, 572 U.S. at 656. 
As to the first prong of the qualified immunity analysis, for purposes of Defendantsโ 
Motion only, the undersigned assumes a constitutional violation under the Fourteenth Amendment 
by Defendants Foot and Grant and the Doe Defendants. With regard to the second prong, however, 
the undersigned agrees with Defendants that it was not clearly established at the time of the arrest 
that any Individual Defendantโs conductโโstrip searching, or allowing strip searching, of female 
pre-classification detainees but not male pre-classification detainees under the circumstances 
presented  at  BCDCโโviolated  Plaintiffsโ  Equal  Protection  rights  under  the  Fourteenth 
Amendment. See ECF No. 49-1 at 13; ECF No. 55 at 8.  
  When inquiring whether a constitutional right is clearly established, a court must first 
โdefine the precise right into which [it is] inquiring.โ Est. of Armstrong ex rel. Armstrong v. Vill. 
of Pinehurst, 810 F.3d 892, 907 (4th Cir. 2016). After defining the right, the court then asks 
whether it was clearly established at the time the officers acted. Id. A right satisfies this standard 
when it is โsufficiently clear that every reasonable official would have understood that what he is 
doing violates that right.โ Mullenix v. Luna, 577 U.S. 7, 11 (2015); Hill v. Crum, 727 F.3d 312, 
321 (4th Cir. 2013). 
21 
 

9:20-cv-02144-DCN       Date Filed 10/28/22      Entry Number 76       Page 22 of 39
For a right to be clearly established, โexisting precedent15 must have placed the statutory 
or constitutional question beyond debate.โ Ashcroft v. al-Kidd, 563 U.S. 731, 741 (2011); see City 
& Cnty. of San Francisco v. Sheehan, 575 U.S. 600, 611 (2015) (โThis exacting standard gives 
government officials breathing room to make reasonable but mistaken judgments by protecting all 
but the plainly incompetent or those who knowingly violate the law.โ) (internal quotation marks 
omitted). โThis is not to say that an official action is protected by qualified immunity unless the 
very action in question has previously been held unlawful, but it is to say that in the light of pre-
existing law the unlawfulness must be apparent.โ Armstrong, 810 F.3d at 907 (quoting Wilson v. 
Layne, 526 U.S. 603, 615 (1999)). Indeed, a right may be clearly established if โa general 
constitutional rule already identified in the decisional law applies with obvious clarity to the 
specific conduct in question.โ Booker v. S.C. Depโt of Corr., 855 F.3d 533, 543 (4th Cir. 2017) 
(alterations omitted) (quoting Hope v. Pelzer, 536 U.S. 730, 741 (2002)); see also Owens ex rel. 
Owens v. Lott, 372 F.3d 267, 279 (4th Cir. 2004) (stating that a right may be clearly established if 
it is โmanifestly apparent from broader applications of the constitutional premise in questionโ). 
Thus, officers can be โon notice that their conduct violates established law even in novel factual 
circumstances.โ Armstrong, 810 F.3d at 907 (quoting Hope, 536 U.S. at 741).  
Nonetheless, even though general statements of law may provide notice, courts must not 
โdefine clearly established law at a high level of generality,โ Mullenix, 577 U.S. at 12 (quoting al-
 
15 โThe universe of existing precedent is not unlimited,โ and courts in the Fourth Circuit โordinarily 
need not look beyond the decisions of the Supreme Court, th[e] Fourth Circuit court of appeals, 
and the highest court of the state in which the case arose.โ West v. Murphy, 771 F.3d 209, 213 (4th 
Cir. 2014) (citations and internal quotation marks omitted); see also Ferrera v. Hunt, 2012 U.S. 
Dist. LEXIS 45444 (D.S.C. March 19, 2012), report and recommendation adopted in part, 2012 
U.S. Dist. Lexis (March 28, 2012); but see Booker v. S.C. Depโt of Corr., 855 F.3d 533, 543 (4th 
Cir. 2017) (โIn the absence of controlling authority that specifically adjudicates the right in 
question, a right may still be clearly established . . . based on a consensus of cases of persuasive 
authority from other jurisdictions.โ) (citations and internal quotation marks omitted). 
22 
 

9:20-cv-02144-DCN       Date Filed 10/28/22      Entry Number 76       Page 23 of 39
Kidd, 563 U.S. at 742). Rather, courts must examine โwhether the violative nature of particular 
conduct is clearly established.โ Id. (emphasis in original) (quoting al-Kidd, 563 U.S. at 742). This 
examination is โundertaken in light of the specific context of the case, not as a broad general 
proposition.โ Id. (quoting Brosseau v. Haugen, 543 U.S. 194, 198 (2004)). โIf the right was not 
clearly established in the specific context of the case โ that is, if it was not clear to a reasonable 
[official] that the conduct in which he allegedly engaged was unlawful in the situation he 
confronted โ then the law affords immunity from suit.โ Parrish v. Cleveland, 372 F.3d 294, 301 
(4th Cir. 2004). 
Plaintiffs argue that, at the time they were strip searched, โequal protection rights in the 
prison context were well established.โ ECF No. 56 at 16.  Plaintiffs define the relevant issue as the 
โdifferential treatment of male and female pre-classification detainees regarding strip-searches in 
violation of Plaintiffsโ right to Equal Protection under the Fourteenth Amendment.โ Id. at 19.  
However, framing the issue in this manner, specifically the law regarding equal protection under 
the Fourteenth Amendment, is cast at a high level of generality and does not by itself create clearly 
established law outside an obvious case. 
As noted above, the Supreme Court has held that โcourts must not define clearly established 
law at a high level of generality, since doing so avoids the crucial question whether the official 
acted reasonably in the particular circumstances that he or she faced.โ See District of Columbia v. 
Wesby, 138 S. Ct. 577, 590 (2018). This inquiry โโmust be undertaken in light of the specific 
context of the case, not as a broad general proposition.โโ See Brosseau v. Haugen, 543 U.S. 194, 
198 (2004) (per curiam) (quoting Saucier v. Katz, 533 U.S. 194, 201 (2001)). As the Fourth Circuit 
has โspelled out with specificity, qualified immunity protects law officers from bad guesses in gray 
areas, and it ensures that they may be held personally liable only for transgressing bright lines.โ 
23 
 

9:20-cv-02144-DCN       Date Filed 10/28/22      Entry Number 76       Page 24 of 39
Gomez v. Atkins, 296 F.3d 253, 261 (4th Cir. 2002) (citation and internal quotation marks omitted).  
Here, the relevant issue for purposes of qualified immunity is whether strip searching 
female  pre-classification  detainees  but  not  male  pre-classification  detainees  violates  equal 
protection where the female pre-classification area is in general population and the male pre-
classification area is not. The parties do not point to any controlling authority from the United 
States Supreme Court, the Fourth Circuit or this District sufficiently similar to the situation the 
individual Defendants confronted in this case that would have made clear to them that their conduct 
under BCDCโs Practice violated Plaintiffsโ equal protection rights. Nor is there a consensus of 
cases of persuasive authority from other jurisdictions that would otherwise make it โsufficiently 
clear that every reasonable official would have understoodโ that what the individual Defendants 
did in this case violated that right. See Mullenix, 577 U.S. at 11; Hill, 727 F.3d at 321. 
Notably, prior to BCDCโs Practice, the United States Supreme Court held that the Fourth 
Amendment does not prohibit a policy requiring the strip searching of all detainees who will be in 
a jailโs general population. See Florence, 566 U.S. at 333โ34. Defendant Grant testified that 
โ[o]nce the case law came out saying that we could strip search prior to them entering general 
population, then we changed.โ ECF No. 48-1, Grant Dep. at 41:17โ20. The issue here under the 
Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment arises from the different locations of the 
pre-classification areas for men and women at the time at BCDC. Under these circumstances, the 
undersigned cannot find that the law was โsufficiently clear that every reasonable official would 
have understood that what he is doing violates that right.โ Mullenix, 577 U.S. at 11; Hill, 727 F.3d 
at 321. 
24 
 

9:20-cv-02144-DCN       Date Filed 10/28/22      Entry Number 76       Page 25 of 39
Accordingly, the undersigned recommends finding that Defendants Grant and Foot, as well 
as any Doe Defendants, are entitled to qualified immunity on Plaintiffsโ ยง 1983 claim under the 
Fourteenth Amendment and granting their Motion for Summary Judgment on this claim.

C. Outrage (Count 6), Assault (Count 7) and Battery (Count 8) Claims  
Plaintiffsโ sixth cause of action is for โreckless infliction of emotional distress/outrageโ 
against Defendant Beaufort County only. Plaintiffsโ seventh cause of action is for assault against 
all Defendants. Plaintiff Mundayโs eighth cause of action is for battery against all Defendants.  
Plaintiff Devine did not assert a claim for battery. 
Defendants argue that,  under the provisions of the South Carolina Tort Claims Act 
(โSCTCAโ), Defendant Beaufort County is not liable for intentional infliction of emotional harm 
or other intentional conduct by an employee. ECF No. 48-1 at 21โ22. They also contend that 
Plaintiffsโ claims for assault and Plaintiff Mundayโs claim for battery are barred by the SCTCA. 
Id. at 23โ25. 
A โlossโ under the SCTCA includes โbodily injury, disease, death, or damage to tangible 
property, including lost wages and economic loss to the person who suffered the injury, disease, 
or death, pain and suffering, mental anguish, and any other element of actual damages recoverable 
in actions for negligence, but does not include the intentional infliction of emotional harm.โ See 
S.C. Code ยง 15-78-30(f). Additionally, a government entity is not liable for โemployee conduct 
outside the scope of his official duties or which constitutes actual fraud, actual malice, intent to 
harm, or a crime involving moral turpitude.โ See S.C. Code ยง 15-78-60(17).  
a.  Outrage (Count 6) 
With regard to the claim for outrage, Plaintiffs agree that a โlossโ under the SCTCA does 
not include โintentionalโ infliction of emotional harm and that a governmental entity is not liable 
for employee conduct that constitutes an intent to harm. ECF No. 56 at 22. Indeed, there is no 
dispute here that intentional infliction of emotional harm is not a recoverable loss against Beaufort 
County under the SCTCA.  
26 
 

9:20-cv-02144-DCN       Date Filed 10/28/22      Entry Number 76       Page 27 of 39
However, Plaintiffs emphasize they have not alleged that any Defendantโs actions were 
โintentionalโ but, instead, contend they were โreckless.โ Indeed, the title of Count Six is โReckless 
Infliction of Emotional Distress (Outrage),โ and the allegations are limited to โrecklessโ conduct, 
not โintentional conflict.โ ECF No. 12 at 18, ยถ 72 (the Defendants โrecklessly discriminated in 
their treatment of Plaintiffsโ), ยถ 77 (Defendantsโ conduct โwas recklessโ), ยถ 81 (โCounty should 
be held liable to Plaintiffs . . . given [the individual Defendantsโ] reckless infliction of emotional 
distressโ). Nor have Defendants pointed to any evidence that would prove otherwise, specifically 
that the only evidence before the Court involves intentional and not reckless conduct.   
While the cause of action is traditionally referred to as โoutrageโ or โintentional infliction 
of emotional distress,โ it includes reckless conduct. Specifically, โ[t]o recover for outrageโ
otherwise known as intentional infliction of emotional distressโa plaintiff must establish[, among 
other elements], the following: (1) the defendant intentionally  or recklessly inflicted severe 
emotional distress, or was certain, or substantially certain, that such distress would result from his 
conduct.โ Bass v. S.C. Depโt of Soc. Servs., 780 S.E.2d 252, 260 (S.C. 2015) (emphasis added) 
(quoting Argoe v. Three Rivers Behavioral Health, L.L.C., 710 S.E.2d 67, 74 (S.C. 2011) (citing 
Hansson v. Scalise Builders of S.C., 650 S.E.2d 68, 70โ71 (S.C. 2007))); Ford v. Hutson, 276 
S.E.2d 776, 778 (S.C. 1981).  
Defendants argue for liberal construction of the SCTCA to bar this claim, citing to the 
statute and numerous cases that have concluded the SCTCA bars outrage claims. ECF No. 48-1 at 
21โ23; see also S.C. Code Ann. ยง 15-78-20(f) (โ. . . limitation[s] on an exemption to the liability 
of the state . . . must be liberally construed in favor of limiting the liability of the state.โ). However, 
the cases cited by Defendants involve claims for โintentionalโ infliction of emotional distress, 
addressing the intentional aspect of the cause of action. But South Carolina courts have made clear 
27 
 

9:20-cv-02144-DCN       Date Filed 10/28/22      Entry Number 76       Page 28 of 39
that while negligent conduct cannot give rise to an intentional infliction of emotional distress, 
either intentional or reckless conduct can. See, e.g., Bergstrom v. Palmetto Health All., 596 S.E.2d 
42, 48โ49 (S.C. 2004) (explaining that if defendant hospital โrecklessly or intentionally made 
repeated and coercive efforts to separate a mother from her newborn infant, that might well 
constitute  outrageous  conduct  that  .  .  .  conceivably  could  cause  severe  emotional  distress. 
However, the evidence presented at trial revealed that, while Hospitalโs staff arguably may have 
acted negligently in failing to follow certain policies, the staff did not act recklessly or intentionally 
in the extreme or outrageous manner described in the complaint,โ such that a directed verdict at 
trial would have been appropriate) (emphasis added). 
As Plaintiffs note, a plain reading of the SCTCA indicates that only intentional, not 
reckless, conduct is included, and โ[t]he Court is not required to examine statutory construction 
when the statute is plain and unambiguous.โ Thao v. Nationwide Affinity Ins. Co. of Am., No. 7:17-
CV-02403-AMQ, 2018 WL 2971784, at *4 (D.S.C. June 13, 2018) โLegislative history only can 
be resorted to for the purpose of solving doubt, not for the purpose of creating it.โ Id. (quoting 
Timmons v. S.C. Tricentennial Commโn, 254 175 S.E.2d 805, 817 (S.C. 1970)). 
In this case, Plaintiffs limited the allegations in their Amended Complaint to โrecklessโ 
conduct. Therefore, the undersigned cannot say, at this stage of the litigation, that the claims are 
barred by the SCTCA. See Bass, 780 S.E.2d at 258, 261 (upholding general jury verdict against 
state agency on SCTCA claims of gross negligence and outrage premised on reckless conduct). 
Moreover, Defendants do not present any other arguments in support of summary judgment on 
this clam. Accordingly, the undersigned recommends denying Defendantsโ Motion for Summary 
Judgment on this claim, as set forth in Plaintiffsโ Amended Complaint.
